awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research Belmont Forum: People, poll
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support to U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a six-country initiative on global change research through the Belmont Forum. The Belmont Forum is a group of the world?s major and emerging funders of global environmental change research. It aims to accelerate delivery of the international environmental research most urgently needed to remove critical barriers to sustainability by aligning and mobilizing international resources. Each partner organization provides funding for researchers from their country to alleviate the need for funds to cross international borders.  This approach facilitates effective leveraging of national resources to support excellent research on topics of global relevance best tackled through a multinational approach, recognizing that global challenges need global solutions.

Working together in a Collaborative Research Action, the six partner organizations have provided support for research projects that utilize a strong inter- and trans-disciplinary approach to examine climate, environmental, and related societal change in mountain regions. This award provides support for the U.S. researchers to cooperate in a consortium of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that brings together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., policy makers, regulators, NGOs, communities and industry).  

This project will determine the effects of pollution, pathogens and human impacts on mountain ecosystems at the interface of aquatic and terrestrial habitats. The research will be conducted in four mountain ranges (Pyrenees, France; Dhofar Mountains, Oman; Sierra Nevada, USA; and Great Hinggan Mountains, China), and will take place along similar elevations.  The use historical and newly collected data, to develop indicators of change, and develop and define essential biodiversity variables relevant for the mountain regions that can be used in models as well as by the general public, stakeholders and policymakers.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project is to study how pollution, pathogens and anthropological impacts (people) affect a key ecosystem often located at the interphase between humans, wildlife, ecosystems and global environmental change: mountain ecosystems. In particular, this project focuses on the interface of aquatic and terrestrial habitats. As part of the Belmont Challenge, this project builds international partnerships in interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary scientific research and seeks to remove critical barriers to sustainability. The project brings together research expertise in an international collaboration funded independently from each participating country in order forge scientific partnerships and build scientific capacity in the United States (this project), France, Germany, and China. For this project, the field research is integrated across four mountain ranges around the world: the Pyrenees (France, Spain), Dhofar Mountains (Oman), Sierra Nevada (USA) and the Great Hinggan Mountains (China). Each mountain range has shared characteristics with the others, but, they also have key differences, which allows for the analysis of hypothesis testing in different ecological contexts that should result in more generalizable outcomes.

 

Intellectual Merrit: The USA part of the project (this study) contributes significantly to research in all of the study mountain ranges by studying the relationship between the health of a key group of mountain vertebrates (amphibians) and ecosystem health, by providing expertise and training to scientific collaborators and students in all of the member teams, by analyzing data collected on amphibians by all of the research teams, and by helping to develop a common database combining information on the different mountain ranges that are relevant to the overall project. To this end, this project has developed methodologies to track the spread of fungal pathogens of amphibians, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), and Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) that cause the deadly disease called chytridiomycosis. This project has also utilized next generation sequencing to characterize and describe the skin microbial communities of amphibians, a factor previously shown to be associated with the health and disease of amphibians. The study organisms include many of the amphibians that inhabit the aquatic and terrestrial habitats of the Sierra Nevada (as well as those that occur in mountain ranges in other parts of the world) including frogs and salamanders, as well as the fungal pathogens Bd and Bsal and the microbial species that live in symbiosis with the amphibians and in their surrounding environment.

 

Broader Outcomes: The project made significant progress by creating a publicly available database, the Amphibian Disease Portal (www.amphibiandisease.org) that shares information on disease in amphibians freely with the public. The site now includes data from over 80,000 individual tests (qPCR assays) collected from 2814 amphibian species collected in 128 countries around the world.  This project allows researchers to share information within their projects (under password protection) but also has a public side where data can be shared with any user. The data portal also provides Digital Object Identifiers (DOI) that are used in scientific publications to allow users to go directly to archived data. It enables users to easily download raw data used in scientific publications.  The project created training videos available through the project website (https://www.p3mountains.org),  through the VredenburgLab Youtube channel ( https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCgkA-0MC3XnUQ3Vt6ai7F2g ), and through AmphibiaWeb (https://amphibiaweb.org). Some of the training videos are meant for other scientists conducting disease ecology research (e.g. ?How to swab a preserved amphibian.?), while others are meant for the general public (e.g. ?How to find salamanders?).  The project also supported undergraduate and graduate students at San Francisco State University in San Francisco, California, USA. This University is recognized as a Hispanic Serving Institution.

 


Last Modified: 04/22/2022
Modified by: Vance Vredenburg
